units.title: Clean and isolate crypts from colon tissue
units.text: To clean the tissue and isolate fresh crypts for organoid generation, colon tissue was first sliced open lengthwise and wiped 3–4 times with gauze (Fisher Scientiﬁc) to remove waste and mucus. The tissue was then cut into small sections of ~2” × 2” and placed into a 15 cm dish ﬁlled with PBS++ (PBS supplemented with 10 mM HEPES (Thermo Fisher Scientiﬁc), 1X GlutaMAX (Thermo Fisher Scientiﬁc), 1X Pen-Strep (Thermo Fisher Scientiﬁc), and 2.5 μg/mL Amphotericin B (Thermo Fisher Scientiﬁc). The epithelium was then minced from tissue segments using scalpels (Fisher Scientiﬁc) and collected into 50 mL conical tubes. Minced epithelium was washed 3 times with DMEM++ (Advanced DMEM/F12 (Thermo Fisher Scientiﬁc) supplemented with 10 mM HEPES, 1X GlutaMAX, 1X Pen-Strep, and 2.5 μg/mL Amphotericin B), and centrifuged at 4 °C, 500 × g for 3 min between each wash.
units.rationale: This is a step-by-step procedural instruction for preparing colon tissue to isolate crypts, essential for organoid generation.

units.title: Digest tissue with EDTA to release crypts
units.text: After the ﬁnal wash, tissue was resuspended in 25 mL of 2.5 mM EDTA in PBS and placed in an end-over-end rotator at 37 °C until crypts were visible, around 12 min. Following digestion, the EDTA digestion solution was topped up with 20 mL of DMEM++, ﬁltered through sterile gauze, and centrifuged for 3 min at 4 °C, 500 × g.
units.rationale: This describes a specific, time-controlled enzymatic digestion step to release crypts, a critical protocol action.

units.title: Plate crypts in Matrigel for organoid formation
units.text: The pellet was then resuspended in 10 mL PBS+++, ﬁltered through a 100 µm cell strainer, and centrifuged for 3 min at 4 °C, 500. The tissue was then ready for plating in Matrigel (Corning) by resuspending in cold Matrigel and plating into 30 μL Matrigel droplets, at a density of 30–50 crypts per droplet. Once Matrigel had solidiﬁed for 30 min at 37 °C, crypts were fed with organoid growth media.
units.rationale: This details the precise procedure for embedding crypts in Matrigel to initiate organoid culture, including critical temperature and timing steps.

units.title: Maintain organoid growth media
units.text: Organoid growth media: Advanced DMEM/F12 supplemented with 1X Pen-Strep, 10 mM HEPES, 1X GlutaMAX, 1X B-27 Supplement (Thermo Fisher Scientiﬁc), 0.2 nM Wnt Surrogate protein (ImmunoPrecise Antibodies), 5 nM Gastrin-1 (Tocris), 1.25mM N-Acetyl-L-Cysteine (Sigma-Aldrich), 10 mM Nicotinamide (Sigma-Aldrich), 100 µg/mL Primocin (InvivoGen), 500 nM A 83-01 (Tocris), 50 ng/mL recombinant human EGF (R&D Systems), 100 ng/mL recombinant human Noggin (R&D Systems), 250 ng/mL recombinant human R-spondin 3 (Roche), 100 ng/mL recombinant human IGF1 (BioLegend), 50 ng/mL recombinant human FGF2 (PeproTech).
units.rationale: This is a verbatim list of components for organoid growth media, a core protocol requirement for consistent culture.

units.title: Passage organoids using EDTA and Trypsin
units.text: To passage, organoids were mechanically dislodged from Cultrex domes using a P1000 pipette tip and resuspended in cold 10 mM EDTA with 10 µM Y-27632 (STEMCELL Technologies) in a 15 mL conical tube. The tube containing organoids was then placed on an end-over-end rotator at 4 °C for 30 min and then centrifuged for 5 min at 500 ×g, 4 °C. Organoids were then resuspended in 1X Trypsin (Fisher Scientiﬁc) and placed in an end-over-end rotator for 6 min at 37 °C. Following dissociation, Trypsin was neutralized with DMEM containing 10% FBS, and organoids were centrifuged for 5 min at 500 × g, 4 °C.
units.rationale: This is a detailed, sequential protocol for organoid passaging, including reagents, timing, and centrifugation parameters.

units.title: Seed organoids in microwell plates
units.text: Experiments involving microwell plates utilized 500 µm Gri3D plates (SUN bioscience). Prior to organoid seeding, storage buffer was aspirated from each well and 150 µL of Advanced DMEM/F12 was added through the pipetting port. The plate was placed in the tissue culture incubator for at least 30 min. Organoids that had been maintained in Cultrex domes for at least 5 days after passaging were removed from the ECM following the passaging protocol as above, but dissociated for 12 min in Trypsin rather than 6, or until organoids were largely single cells. Trypsin was neutralized and organoids were washed as in the passaging protocol. Following the PBS wash, organoids were resuspended in organoid growth media without Nicotinamide: Advanced DMEM/F12 supplemented with 1X Pen-Strep, 10 mM HEPES, 1X GlutaMAX, 1X B-27 Supplement, 0.2 nM Wnt Surrogate protein, 5 nM Gastrin-1, 1.25mM N-Acetyl-L-Cysteine, 100 µg/mL Primocin, 500 nM A 83-01, 50 ng/mL recombinant human EGF, 100 ng/mL recombinant human Noggin, 250 ng/mL recombinant human R-spondin 3, 100 ng/mL recombinant human IGF1, 50 ng/mL recombinant human FGF2, and with 10 µM Y-27632. Dissociated organoids were then counted using a hemocytometer and seeded into the microwell plates at a density of 200 cells per microwell, in 50 µL of media per well. The plates were placed in the incubator for 30–60 min to allow the cells to settle, after which another 100 µL of media containing 2% Matrigel was added per well. It is critical that Matrigel is added to the media while cold.
units.rationale: This is a comprehensive, actionable protocol for seeding organoids into microwell plates with precise cell density, media composition, and temperature requirements.

units.title: Apply DSS injury to organoids
units.text: For DSS treatment, DSS (MP Biomedicals) was dissolved in organoid media (without EGF or Nicotinamide), and added to organoid wells overnight for 16 h, after which organoids were washed twice with Advanced DMEM/F12 and then replaced with organoid media. The low and high doses considered were 0.1% DSS and 0.5% (wt/vol) DSS in media.
units.rationale: This provides a clear, reproducible protocol for inducing epithelial injury using DSS with defined concentration and exposure time.

units.title: Apply cytomix injury to organoids
units.text: For cytomix treatment, human recombinant TNFɑ (R&D Systems), IFNɣ (R&D systems), and IL-1β (PeproTech) were dissolved in organoid media (without EGF or Nicotinamide) for 8 hours, after which organoids were washed twice with Advanced DMEM/F12 and then replaced with organoid media. The low and high doses considered were 10 ng/mL TNFɑ, 10 ng/mL IFNɣ, 1 ng/mL IL1β and 50 ng/mL TNFɑ, 50 ng/mL IFNɣ, 5 ng/mL IL1β.
units.rationale: This is a precise, quantitative protocol for applying inflammatory cytokine mix (cytomix) to organoids with defined doses and exposure duration.

units.title: Measure organoid permeability with FITC-dextran
units.text: Organoid permeability and apoptosis measurements were conducted on one day post-injury, and FITC-dextran was used to assess barrier integrity. Briefly, organoids were incubated in a solution of 4kDA FITC-Dextran (MedChemExpress) diluted to 2 mg/mL in PBS for 5 min in µ-slides (Ibidi) to allow organoids to settle to the bottom of the slide. Organoids were then imaged on a Nikon spinning disc confocal to collect ﬂuorescence and DIC images, and the percentage of intact organoids was calculated as the number of organoids per condition/donor that excluded FITC-dextran from the lumen divided by the total number of organoids.
units.rationale: This is a standardized, quantitative protocol for measuring epithelial barrier function using FITC-dextran exclusion.

units.title: Quantify apoptosis with Caspase-3/7 reagent
units.text: For apoptosis quantiﬁcation, organoids were incubated in CellEvent Caspase-3/7 Detection Reagent (Thermo Fisher) diluted in media according to manufacturer protocols for 30 min in the microwell plates. Organoids were then washed with PBS and imaged on a Nikon spinning disc confocal to collect ﬂuorescence and DIC images. The % area of caspase was quantiﬁed using FIJI66 as the area of organoid stained positive for Caspase-3/7 divided by the total area of the organoid from DIC images.
units.rationale: This is a reproducible, image-based protocol for quantifying apoptosis using a validated fluorescent reagent and analysis method.
